Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: @crunchycat  from a business perspective, why would I pay 3x more to do the same job

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: @crunchycat Also with the percentage mining model,  itâ€™s not cost effective even for the customer chains.   You say even large chains will want VBK,  imagine there is a coin similar in price and marketcap and mining parameters as Komodo. About 2.6 million coins are mined per year. 26000 coins at 1% mining fee roughly 26k usd ,  this is 4-5x the cost of Komodo DPoW.  And only gets worse with more capitalized chains.  Lower end chains face the problems a) no way to recuperate shitcoin for btc spent b) low value coins being split up = tragedy of the commons

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 1576800 coins mined per year, still the cost is quite a bit higher

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Ah yes My mistake, yes it still is like 3x higher.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but KMD has pretty low mining emission due to the 5% APR, most other mining coins are issuing all new coins via mining, so it could be 3x more than 3x

Author: Regnar#6164
Content: loving the docs page btw, it's coming along!

Author: Regnar#6164
Content: The new quantum resistance is all about making keypairs so big it just crashes your computer when you try to use it.

Author: Spaid#3606
Content: quantum secure is saying technology will never advance to break it... doesn't matter how big the key is, someday it will be broken

Author: Regnar#6164
Content: It's more just saying we changed the problem being asked to one that is more difficult for a quantum computer to solve, assuming we understand HOW the computers will try and solve them.

Author: Regnar#6164
Content: There very well may be a new algorithm that QC will use that may break lattice based encryption, by that I mean just give it an advantage to some degree in solving it, but then we have to change the problem being asked again. repeat forever

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: just because you cant be sure the new algo will remain quantum resistant, it is sure better than continuing to use obsolete algo that we know are totally cracked.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: when QC arrive, we need to transition

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: will it be dilithium? who knows?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but we can practice ahead of time what the anti-QC migration would be like and solve whatever issues we encounter in the early ones

Author: Regnar#6164
Content: It's definitely good to have a grasp of both sides of the situation. Seeing how computers and tech are evolving, what they are doing better, where their limitations are etc. and then finding hard problems that can only be solved (that we know of) in ways that those computers are not good at.
